ratings.comment: Loved Molly and J201! I'm a freshman, and this was easily my favorite class I took this year. If you attend lecture, keep up with the readings, and participate in section you will do great. Even if you're not going into Journalism, the course concepts are super interesting, relevant, and easy to grasp. I would recommend this class to everyone.

It's an easy class, pay attention in lecture, and read and you'll get an A easily. The TAs grade everything so you'll usually get good grades on your essays. There are pop quizzes, but all you need to do is follow CNN on Twitter and read their feed every once in a while.

Not a big fan personally. She comes off as self-absorbed & pretentious. She doesn't deliver a lot of the teachings in a finite understandable manner. She tries to be fun & giddy but is annoying & exasperating. TA's are ethnic & do not understand English, so grading was relatively easy. But Molly graded certain assignments & was a tough grader.

I loved this class so much! She is a great professor the lectures aren't really that necessary to attend to pass the class but they are very interesting. You must read every week if you want a good weekly quiz grade and you don't want to have to go through them for the midterm and final. The midterm and final are take home, it's great!

She tends to read off her slides a lot in lecture which is a shame because she's clearly a very intelligent person. There are a lot of moving parts in the class but she stays on top of things for the most part.  P.S: Don't bother buying the reader for her class as she puts all the readings online anyway
I personally like her lectures, she does have some attitude in how she talks and teaches in a more left-leaning manner.  Her slides are online but I think it's better to go to lecture.

There's a LOT going on in this class: weekly current events quiz, 1 impromptu speech, one planned speech, weekly 500 word essay, readings, 2 media analysis essays (1000 wrd), and 1 discussion leading. It's well laid out and spread out, though and if you like to write the topics are interesting. Molly is quirky and fun. Lectures are interesting.

Really knowledgeable since she has two Ivy League degrees. However, she's very liberal and it's obvious from lectures (if that's not your thing, you'll hate her). Not afraid to call students out in class or on Twitter. Good at what she does but definitely pray that you have an easy TA for your grading. Extra credit was my lifesaver for her.

Prof. Steenson was a great professor, although sometimes lectures got a little boring. She makes her slides available online so you technically could skip lecture, but you won't want to. She's really helpful if you show interest in the subject, and she's flexible with meeting after class. We had plenty of guest speakers as well.

All she really does is read the slides off the screen. Injects personal views into much of it, and it's unclear usually as to what precisely she wanted us to learn. Overall, would not take this class again unless the other prof. was doing it. Lost much of my interest in the subject. Only plus is grading is easy.

She "requires" you to buy a reader- don't, she puts all articles online for you. It was just a waste of 30$. She is a nice person and has good intentions. However, she is very ambiguous and concepts are extremely hard to grasp (coming from a journalism major). I would recommend the class only if there is another professor available.

Molly is awesome! So down to earth and relatable. She is very interested in Journalism and Strategic Communications and gets the class into it as well. Offers extra credit for tweeting! Overall, a great teacher, very up with technology, funny, and really helpful! Definitely recommend this class. Favorite professor and class I've taken at UW so far
